item.title: Monsters
item.description: It’s harder to keep regularly plugging away at something non-work during this time. I hear we shouldn’t expect too much of ourselves and…
item.content:encoded:
It’s harder to keep regularly plugging away at something non-work during this time. I hear we shouldn’t expect too much of ourselves and each other…

Making a start on painting some monsters into this picture: Chapter Six.

item.title: Viral
item.description: Well. That was interesting. It’s COVID-19 lockdown day 3 here in New Zealand. Discombobulating times. I could blame my inactivity in…
item.content:encoded:
Well. That was interesting.

It’s COVID-19 lockdown day 3 here in New Zealand. Discombobulating times. I could blame my inactivity in personal learning projects entirely on SARS-COV-2, but the truth is I’ve been conking out pretty early and consuming content without creating any. I hate that: feels like empty time.

So, let’s see how many of these crisis days I can fill with creativity, when I’m not at my ‘day job’. Since I’m already a remote worker, I haven’t had to make too many adjustments in that department and I have absolutely no excuse not to stretch into learning a bit more.

I think we’re up to Chapter Five.

Ooo, field of view is interesting. But this room algorithm creates very tall, skinny rooms!

item.title: Green Walls
item.description: Chapter 3. Random walls. I know how you feel sometimes, little symbol.
item.content:encoded: Chapter 3. Random walls. I know how you feel sometimes, little @ symbol.

item.title: Quickly Catching Up
item.description: I like Rust. I have some programmerly reasons for that, the ones I know I’m supposed to approve of like memory safety, strong typing…
item.content:encoded:
I like Rust. I have some programmerly reasons for that, the ones I know I’m supposed to approve of like memory safety, strong typing, sensible error handling, no garbage collector, and so on. On a personal level though, it just feels elegant. Which is rather flimsy language to use to think about a technical topic, but I don’t care. It’s also a much-needed break from JavaScript/TypeScript which, as necessary as they are these days, still feel a bit tiresome.

I’ve been a repentant dabbler in Rust for several years. I’ve been down the “write a Roguelike in Rust” road before, but never finished it. I hope to move past that phase now and Build Some Shit.

Still, that means the first pages of Herbert’s tutorial are mostly old news, so I’m skimming.

We’ll track this project at vimhack.

item.title: Every Day
item.description: Since becoming a home owner for the first time, I’ve been enjoying things that have rhythm. I’m trying to lever out a little time every day…
item.content:encoded:
Since becoming a home owner for the first time, I’ve been enjoying things that have rhythm. I’m trying to lever out a little time every day for personal learning and play, amid the Möbius-like stream of house-related tasks (buying a home built in the 1950s has its moments!)

I like Roguelikes. I’m going to be doing a little of Herbert Wolverson’s excellent Roguelike Tutorial - In Rust each day. I suspect sometimes a very little.
